Issues.Title: NextJS and v4 Beta does not see class
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**
v4.0.0-beta.9

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**
NextJS: 15.1.4
@tailwindcss/postcss: 4.0.0-beta.9

**What version of Node.js are you using?**
v20.9.0

**Reproduction URL**
https://github.com/[maddog986/nextjs-tailwindv4](https://github.com/maddog986/nextjs-tailwindv4)

**Describe your issue**

None of the classes defined in any of the *.tsx files are being processed in the output css.

I have spent more than a few hours trying different configurations in a private project, however I could not get any class names to appear in the output CSS in either dev or build modes. I even tried the @sources to manually include the files, custom tailwind.config.js to define "content" sources, but nothing I tried seemed to work. Even the NextJS playground does not work correctly.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NextJS and v4 Beta does not see class" (#15604)

Issues.Title: TAILWIND - I don't even know what to say
Issues.Body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/discussions/12915
Originally posted by **tgsutterby** February 10, 2024 I have to start out by apologizing because I am frustrated beyond belief and mentally I just don't even want to be nice right now. I want to throw something somewhere and see something suffer to make myself feel better lol. I am trying, and let me clarify that I have spent HOURS AND HOURS trying to get Tailwind set up for a new build. This is my first time trying tailwind. I have had ChatGPT help me try to set it up. I have watched YouTube videos by people who supposedly know how to set it up. I have started THREE completely fresh builds and followed the Tailwind set up process directly by copy and paste from their website, and NONE of it has worked. I drop my first component into my index.html file and the formatting is off. The ONLY way I have gotten Tailwind to work correctly so far is by including the CDN in the HTML file, which everyone everywhere says is the wrong way to go, but the only way that seems to work. WTF. What could I be doing wrong? It is so so so so so so so frustrating to following instructions to the letter and have it not work right from the start. Please, for the love of god, someone help. I don't even know what to do anymore. [package-lock.json](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/files/14230139/package-lock.json) [package.json](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/files/14230140/package.json) This is my HTML. The only one I have so far. ` Propel Admin Sign-In

Sign in to your account

Forgot password?

Not a member? Start a 14 day free trial

` This is my input.css which is located in the src folder. `@tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities;` This is my tailwind.config.js file. '/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ module.exports = { content: [ "./public/index.html", ], theme: { extend: {}, }, plugins: [ require('@tailwindcss/forms'), ], }'
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "TAILWIND - I don't even know what to say" (#15601)

Issues.Title: Ensure namespace reset with escaped `*` works
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Ensure namespace reset with escaped `*` works" (#15603)

Issues.Title: [v4] Namespace override syntax is not valid CSS
Issues.Body:
I'm using a CSS formatter ([biome](https://github.com/biomejs/biome)) that won't parse namespace overrides, e.g: `--font-*`, because it is not a valid `ident-token` according to https://drafts.csswg.org/css-syntax-3/#ident-token-diagram

I see two possibilities:
- Keep the current syntax:
  In this case we should also support the escaped version (which is valid CSS syntax), e.g: `--font-\*: initial;`.
- Change the syntax:
  The simplest alternative would be to drop the asterisk, e.g `--font: initial;`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[v4] Namespace override syntax is not valid CSS" (#15602)

Issues.Title: Improve upgrade tool to pretty print `--spacing(2)`
Issues.Body:
This PR improves the upgrade tool to make sure that newly upgraded `--spacing(2)` CSS functions is pretty printed to prevent unambiguous looking classes (even though it compiles correctly).

If you have a class such as `m-[calc(100dvh-theme(spacing.2))]`, then we used to convert it to `m-[calc(100dvh-calc(var(--spacing)*2))]`. But recently we introduced the `--spacing(2)` CSS function which means that the output now looks like this instead: `m-[calc(100dvh---spacing(2))]`.

The triple `-` is valid because the first `-` is the minus sign, the next two `-` characters are from the function.

One solution is to introduce spaces via underscores:

```
m-[calc(100dvh_-_--spacing(2))]
```

But a simpler solution, is to wrap the `--spacing(2)` in parens to remove the underscores and improve the readability of the `---` characters.

```
m-[calc(100dvh-(--spacing(2)))]
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Improve upgrade tool to pretty print `--spacing(2)`" (#15596)

Issues.Title: Add missing `main` field for `@tailwindcss/browser`
Issues.Body:
This PR adds a `main` and `browser` field for the `@tailwindcss/browser` package.

In the package, we do have the `exports` field setup, which is an alternative to the `main` field according to the docs:

> The "exports" provides a modern alternative to "main" ‚Ä¶
>
> ‚Äî https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v10/configuring-npm/package-json?v=true#exports

However, if you look at the unpkg link: https://unpkg.com/@tailwindcss/browser, it tries to load the `index.js` file. This is probably a bug in the unpkg resolver.

That said, if you look at other CDNs such as esm.sh, it does resolve correctly: https://esm.sh/@tailwindcss/browser

According to the npm docs:

> If `main` is not set, it defaults to `index.js` in the package's root folder.
>
> ‚Äî https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v10/configuring-npm/package-json?v=true#main

This explains why unpkg is trying to load the `index.js` file.


Additionally, the npm docs also mention the `browser` field:

> If your module is meant to be used client-side the browser field should be used instead of the main field. This is helpful to hint users that it might rely on primitives that aren't available in Node.js modules. (e.g. window)
>
> ‚Äî https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v10/configuring-npm/package-json?v=true#browser

So this PR also adds that field just to be sure.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add missing `main` field for `@tailwindcss/browser`" (#15594)

Issues.Title: Using @reference breaks local svelte styles.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

4.0.0-beta.9

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Sveltekit 2.15.2, Svelte 5.17.3

**What browser are you using?**

N/A

**Describe your issue**

I have Svelte component with some local styles, using `@reference` makes it so  any styles inside it does not work.
```svelte
<button class="filled-button">Click</button>

<style>
        /* Commenting it out makes it work again */
	@reference '../../app.css'

	.filled-button {
		background: red !important;
	}
</style>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Using @reference breaks local svelte styles." (#15590)

Issues.Title: `space-[x/y]-reverse` should switch to `:first-child`
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

v4.0.0-beta.9

**What browser are you using?**

Brave

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/SCP0ZLhlzP

**Describe your issue**

In v4, when using `space-[x/y]-reverse`, I think that `:last-child` should be changed to `:first-child` since the margin is now being added to [left/top]. Otherwise you end up with a scenario where the first child has a margin above or to the left of it, and the second to last and last child have no margin between them.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`space-[x/y]-reverse` should switch to `:first-child`" (#15589)

Issues.Body:
Here is everything you need to know about this update. Please take a good look at what changed and the test results before merging this pull request. ### What changed? #### ‚ú≥Ô∏è enhanced-resolve (5.17.1 ‚Üí 5.18.0) ¬∑ [Repo](https://github.com/webpack/enhanced-resolve)

5.18.0

Features

Does any of this look wrong? Please let us know.

Issues.Title: Improve `--theme()` CSS function to only accept modern syntax
Issues.Body: This PR makes sure that the `--theme(‚Ä¶)` CSS function can only be used with the modern syntax. For backwards compatibility, the `theme(‚Ä¶)` function must be used with the older dot notation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Improve `--theme()` CSS function to only accept modern syntax" (#15580)

Issues.Title: Migrate `theme(‚Ä¶)` to `--theme(‚Ä¶)`, migrate `calc(var(--spacing)*x)` to `--spacing(x)`
Issues.Body:
This PR improves the codemod tool to simplify 2 things:

1. Whenever you have a `theme(‚Ä¶)` call, we try to change it to a `var(‚Ä¶)`, but if that doesn't work for some reason, we will make sure to at least convert it to the more modern `--theme(‚Ä¶)`.
2. When converting `theme(spacing.2)`, we used to convert it to `calc(var(--spacing)*2)`, but now we will convert it to `--spacing(2)` instead.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Migrate `theme(‚Ä¶)` to `--theme(‚Ä¶)`, migrate `calc(var(--spacing)*x)` to `--spacing(x)`" (#15579)

Issues.Title: Upgrade `lightningcss` to `1.29.0`
Issues.Body:
Closes #15438
Closes #15560
Closes #15561
Closes #15562

This PR upgrades `lightningcss` to `1.29.0` and uses the [new feature flag](https://github.com/parcel-bundler/lightningcss/commit/304389600fb655c5b1af55f1946518e9b755b860) to disable the light-dark function transpilation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Upgrade `lightningcss` to `1.29.0`" (#15576)

Issues.Title: Remove all `@keyframes` in reference import mode
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes an issue where JavaScript plugins were still able to contribute `@keyframes` when loaded inside an `@reference` import. This was possible because we only gated the `addBase` API and not the `addUtilities` one which also has a special branch to handle `@keyframe` rules.

To make this work, we have to create a new instance of the plugin API that has awareness of wether the plugin accessing it is inside reference import mode.

## Test plan

Added a unit test that reproduces the issue observed via #15544
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove all `@keyframes` in reference import mode" (#15581)

Issues.Title: Upgrade various root dependencies
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Upgrade various root dependencies" (#15575)

Issues.Title: Add musl binaries to the Standalone CLI
Issues.Body:
Closes #15031

This adds musl binaries for the Standalone CLI on Linux aarch64 (ARM 64-bit) and x86_64 (Intel/AMD 64-bit).

I tested this by temporarily running the release workflow (without publishing) to build the Standalone CLI, downloading the artifacts, and running the musl binaries in two docker containers.

![linux-arm64-musl](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/67fd4748-afe2-44f7-82a1-5a12eafdbc72)

![linux-x64-musl](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/794ad26e-3389-413e-8888-aac054d61eeb)

(sorry for the potato screenshot ‚Äî tested x64 through my AMD Windows machine over parsec)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add musl binaries to the Standalone CLI" (#15567)

Issues.Title: [V4] Cant use variable for stroke-width
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

^4.0.0-beta.8

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

postcss "^8.4.38"

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

For example: v22

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome

**What operating system are you using?**

Windows

**Describe your issue**

If i use `stroke-2` everything works fine.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/571d39ae-5d50-45ed-b4d9-e0a894eeba96)

But if i try to use `stroke-(--stroke-width-icon)`, to use a variable, it compiles to `stroke` instead of `stroke-width`.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/90d52935-7c5e-43cd-9789-9ba44d591889)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[V4] Cant use variable for stroke-width" (#15574)

Issues.Title: Remove extra commas in `ring-inset`
Issues.Body:
<!--

üëã Hey, thanks for your interest in contributing to Tailwind!

**Please ask first before starting work on any significant new features.**

It's never a fun experience to have your pull request declined after investing a lot of time and effort into a new feature. To avoid this from happening, we request that contributors create an issue to first discuss any significant new features. This includes things like adding new utilities, creating new at-rules, or adding new component examples to the documentation.

https://github.com/tailwindcss/tailwindcss/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md

-->
Chore: Remove extra commas in `ring-inset`. 
This comma doesn't seem to have any purpose.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove extra commas in `ring-inset`" (#15571)

Issues.Title: Upgrade: Do not extract class names from functions
Issues.Body:
This PR prevents the migration of utilities detected in function names, e.g.: the use of `shadow` inside `filter: 'drop-shadow(‚Ä¶)'`.

## Test plan

Have content like this in a project you're migrating using the upgrade tool:

```js
{
  filter: 'drop-shadow(0 0 0.5rem #000)'
}
```

This was verified by adding unit tests to the specific codemods and adding an integration test.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Upgrade: Do not extract class names from functions " (#15566)
